Hi guys!

I have heard that 3D Printers with belts that are tensioned using springs have a tendency of having artifacts in the print due to the belt changing tension as the motors change direction.

In a attempt to see if there is indeed a difference in print quality, I sat down today and came up with these brackets. For the MeCreator2, you will need to print 2 of them, and use a total of 4 small zip ties. They are designed to straddle the spring tensioner located on the 2, Y axis belts. They should be secured in place using 2 small zip ties per side where the grooves are on the bracket.

While this was designed for the Geeetech MeCreator2, I can't see why this wouldn't work with other printers using the same tensioning system.

Here is a link to my video for this model: https://youtu.be/Rpw-G5YlMEM

Special thanks to Bastien. The 2 ends of this bracket were made possible by his model listed as the original.

description.text:
I needed a place to mount my 12V overhead fan switch, and wanted to hide and protect the wiring. This fan switch is ONLY for the top mounted 120mm fans that I added to cool the piece while printing. (not the normal fans that come with printer, the PSU fan or main board fans that were also added, but should stay on.).

The pics show the before and after. Note the nice 80mm power supply fan mount from Leo_N - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1865875, and the "Stiffi" brace - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1985444

I made a 2 hole version also, but make sure to use a properly rated switch for the main power. You might need to change the hole sizes also.

These fit the standard power supply that came with my A8. May not fit for others.

The holes are for 20mm round switches.

Please check out my new product The "OFFi" Auto-off switch for ANET A8 at: http://www.ebay.com/sch/i.html?_nkw=jimb15122

description.text:
I just needed a way of storing my Isopropyl cleaning wipes. I looked around on Thingiverse did not find anything that matched what I wanted, so I quickly made some measurements and created this storage box / Dispenser. The Swabs Measure 51x51mm (2” Inch squared) so I added some tolerance to ensure the Swabs would not be tight. I then made the walls 3mm thick and added a slot for easy access/removal. I then thought the sides look boring so I added the Molecular Formula for Isopropyl Alcohol I have also included a version without the Formula.

Hold 50+ Swabs.

If you have any comments or questions please feel free to contact me.

description.text:
I used two 608 bearings. The bearings fit tightly into the tube, but they they slide on and off the supports.

The bearings slightly sit above the edge so that their should be no plastic on plastic contact.

The supports are from Prusa. I just shrunk the nubs that hold the filament tube.

No supports are needed. The tube prints vertical but the bottom bearing stop is chamfered so no supports are needed.

I use PETg. The nubs on the supports are small and I guessing that if you used PLA, they might break. PETg or ABS should be good.

Bearings should slide in without issue.

I scraped each nub on the top of supports. You don't need to cut into it... sanding may make it smoother to slide on and off.

title: Shim for Glass bed Qidi Tech with 10mm rods, customizable thickness

description.text: This is a customizable shim for Qidi Tech 1 printers with 10mm rods, needed when adding a glass bed or other printbed, for instance Fleks3D. The other shims were difficult to adjust, so I designed a simple shim that fits around the Z-axis. The size of this shim is 8x5 cm, thickness of 3mm. Thickness can be adjusted by just stretching the model in the Z-direction, so you can use it with any glass plate thickness you want.

title: Nespresso Latissima Coffee Drip Tray Remix - Larger Mugs/Cups

description.text:
The Nespresso machine coffee cup area is way too small for a decent sized coffee mug/cup and I have had to resort to sliding the drip tray out of the way which results in milk and coffee spill spraying all over the wall etc...

I printed out Niklas's design but unfortunately still alot of my mugs and cups did not fit or needed to be angled to get them under the nozzle. Here is my remixed design which offers even more clearance (more than 2cm more than standard). description.text:
I recently added fenders to my commuter/hybrid bike to keep some of the mud off of my butt and bike. The fenders came with exactly one clip, and it did a DECENT job of holding the fender in place, but towards the back of the rear tire, the fender was flopping around a bit more than I liked, so I decided to design/print up some additional clips.

The first design was a straight replacement for the factory clip. In the off chance I busted the original. The second design stripped out the tall vertical mounting point, and just has the two side loops. That's ultimately what I wanted, since the plan was to zip-tie the clip centered over the rear wheel.

Oh, this is also dependent upon you having some sort of bike rack installed, with a vertical-ish post that you can tie up to...

The models are for a 45mm fender, but you could easily scale it to match whatever you're working with.

The design was made in Autodesk 123D, by carefully measuring every aspect of the factory clip, and then throwing all of those measurements out, and eyeballing a 3d model. It fits so perfectly, that there's absolutely no way it's coming off unless I break it off. That's how awesome I am with my eyeballs. For real though, I measured the inner dimension of the factory clip with a digital caliper, and matched that in my model. Everything else was a guess.

Printer:

Monoprice Dual Extruder

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

whatever works for you

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I recommend printing with 100% infill. You also may want to print in ABS for a hint of flexibility. However, I printed mine in PLA and it's rock solid.

comments.text: Cool stuff. Having used the plastic variety that came with my fenders, I would warn users to add wide washers; the force of compressing a locknut on top of these plastic pieces will squeeze & eventually break it. The metal versions with tabs that bend around the fenders are a better long-term solution.

title: D20 RGB Lamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
3D Printed, Arduino driven, RGB D20 Lamp. Full writeup here:
http://blog.colecago.com/?p=743

Parts:
Arduino - https://www.sparkfun.com/products/11113
LEDs (x5) - https://www.sparkfun.com/products/13282
Power Supply - https://www.sparkfun.com/products/12889
Barrel Jack - https://www.sparkfun.com/products/10785
Push buttons (similar, x2) - https://www.sparkfun.com/products/9190
D20 Translucent - http://amzn.to/2hLp1iy

Notes:

Files are now rotated and should be flat to the bed.

Base gets glued to the electronics compartment using super glue.

Push the pushbutton leads through the switch backing, push the backing up into the electronics compartment with the buttons through, and hot glue it in place. You can wire leads before or after they are in place if you are careful.

I wired ribbon cable to the LEDs and pulled the cable through the holes and put a spot of hot glue where the circuit board sits on the plastic to hold it in place.

Then the electronics can be all wired together.
Power and ground to all the LED's, one digital output pin from the Arduino into the data in on the first LED, then chain the data outs to data ins of the other LEDs, the last LED's data out is not used.

Put ground to one side of both push buttons and then wire the other side of them to two of the digital inputs on the Arduino.

I did add a capacitor to the 5V line in from the barrel jack and then wired the power from there to the Arduino and all the LED boards, you could probably chain the power and ground board to board, but I had the room and didn't want any lights dimmer than another from voltage drops in the wires.

description.text:
Just wanted to create an LED holder for the Prusa i3 MK2, which is fast to print and does the job. The LED holder won't interfere with the print head and the LEDs can be tilted for the desired angle.

I used some LED stripes from Banggood.com ( http://eu.banggood.com/Wholesale-Warehouse-50cm-9W-5630-SMD-36-LED-Waterproof-Rigid-Strip-Cabinet-Light-DC-12V-wp-Eu-933993.html ) but most LED stripes with equal dimensions should work fine. But take care if you LEDs get hot, they will deform PLA.

All you need are the following parts:

2x haken_rahmen_v2
4x klemmteil_v2
2x M3 x 25 mm screws (or longer)
2x M3 hex nuts (self locking prefered)
1x LED stripe

=== German ===
Mein Ziel war es eine LED Halterung für den Prusa i3 MK2 zu erstellen, die schnell gedruckt werden kann und einfach nur funktioniert. Da die LED Halterung auf der Rückseite des Rahmens eingehakt wird, kann sie nicht mit dem Druckkopf kollidieren. Der Winkel der LEDs lässt sich leicht verstellen.

Ich habe LEDs von Banggood bestellt, die im EU Warenlager verfügbar sind: http://eu.banggood.com/Wholesale-Warehouse-50cm-9W-5630-SMD-36-LED-Waterproof-Rigid-Strip-Cabinet-Light-DC-12V-wp-Eu-933993.html
Die LEDs werden auch bei knapp über 12v nur knapp 38 Grad warm und an der Metallschiene nur knapp 30 Grad. Daher reicht PLA dafür aus.

Benötigt werden folgende Teile:

2x haken_rahmen_v2
4x klemmteil_v2
2x M3 x 25 mm Schrauben (länger geht auch)
2x M3 Sechskantmuttern (vorzugsweise mit Klemmteil / selbstsichernd)
1x LED Streifen

Printer:

Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20 %

Notes:

If your LEDs get hot, don't use PLA. Use PETG or ABS instead.

title: 24mm Flashlight Picatinny Swivel Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted to mount a 24mm flashlight to the picatinny rail of my airsoft M4 replica for dark CQB fields.

However a mounted holder was not my style because otherwise I found that my flashlight gave a shadow of my barrel everywhere I aimed.
Hence I designed this mount that can swivel to adjust the position of the flashlight to not have my barrel's shadow in the way.

Also try out the keymod pressure switch mount for this light.
And give the color filter caps a try as well.

GEEETech i3 Pro B Metal

Doesn't Matter

Yes

50%

Notes:

Print the side parts with support, all other parts should be printable without supports.

Assembly

After printing, glue the star into the "sideclick" part.

Also glue the sides into the grip, there are small ridges that will allow for the optimal spacing for most 24mm flashlights.

The spring needed is between 12-13,5mm in outside diameter and around 10mm long.

author: kolovitz

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus Wiring Bracket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
One of the limitations of the stock i3 Plus is the placement of the wiring bracket behind the extruder head. It consumes the two lower holes in the bearing block that are commonly utilized by custom cooling solutions.

This part relocates the bracket to the upper holes and makes room for other cooling solutions like the CiiCooler (Pictured) and Cobra.

Bearing Block Threading

If necessary, tap the bearing block to M4 x 0.7. On my i3 Plus, the threads were missing or poorly cut. On a related note, I recommend a printed bearing block and an LM8LUU bearing in place of the stock one.

Bracket Threading

Tap the small (bottom and rear) holes to M3 x 0.5

2 M4 x 10mm screws (Bracket to Bearing block)
2 M3 x 10mm screws (Circuit board to Bracket)

Please make sure to re-use the little plastic bushing on the screws holding the circuit board down. It is important to prevent the screw heads from cutting into the board coating.

Also be sure the M4 screw heads do not touch the board, there should be a clear gap between them and the board.

Be careful with the wiring! On my Plus, the wiring was long enough to accomodate this position. It is possible yours won't be.

comments.text: Thanks for sharing this. I'm printing it along with the CiiCooler to try and make more consistent cooling with my Plus. Question: which printed bearing block have you had good experience with? Thinking of tackling that at the same time.
comments.author: Orbital

comments.text: I love this thing! I've got it installed on my Plus (a Monoprice Maker Select Plus), and got the CiiiCooler installed successfully. I didn't need to tap any screw holes in the metal or anything! I did end up using a hobby knife to slightly bore out the very tops of the 4 holes that screws are driven into (not through), to let the sheet metal screws get a grip into there. Once they were threaded in once, it was easy to use!

This is a printable stl of the badger CCL, one of the best high-impact scout rifles in Destiny.

Game Play: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w4zJn3OvuQU

I downloaded the STL here: http://www.destinystlgenerator.com/ then cleaned it up (A LOT. details below).

Included is the full model (complete.stl) as well as sections I've sliced to fit on my printer bed (10x10x6). You might need to scale the pieces for your print bed, or cut your own from the full model.

Clean up: barrel, stock and scope shrouds are all reproduced in 123D Design to make them thicker for printing. Side effect is they're also smoother, with a higher poly count.

The scope internals were 'thickened' in meshmixer for printability, but I used the original mesh.

The barrel, receiver and butt are all straight from bungie. would like to rework those as well at some point - to improve the model smoothness.

remixed_from.author: Printbus
remixed_from.title: MakerFarm i3v Heat Bed Wiring Strain Relief

title: MakerFarm i3v Heat Bed Wiring High Strain Relief
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a remix of my other strain relief at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1957391. The remix raises the strain relief surface a distance away from the y-bed without requiring a lot of infill volume, and provides the option to recess the heads of the mounting screws into the top surface of the higher strain relief. An example of an application for this is to provide a strain relief for wiring to the original MK1 style heat bed that has been flipped upside down so that the heat bed circuit traces are towards the print surface, not away from it as in the MakerFarm OEM approach. Recessing the screw heads helps eliminate or reduce any conflict between the screw heads and wiring, or can be used to affect the length of screw required to mount the support to the y-bed.

Two STL files are provided. File 10mm_high_arc_support.stl is an example that raises the strain relief surface 10mm above the print bed for use with a wood-style y-bed. This strain relief would mount to the y-bed using the two holes in the bed MakerFarm intended for a cable tie. File 8mm_high_block_support.stl is an example that raises the strain relief surface 8mm above the print bed for use with the optional MakerFarm aluminum y-bed. This strain relief would mount to an aluminum bed using holes that have been drilled into the aluminum plate, perhaps using the strain relief as a hole pattern.

A zip tie is used to tighten the wiring from the heated bed to the extending leg of the strain relief.

The gallery photo shows the 10mm_high_arc_support.stl version installed on an 8-inch i3v with the MK1 heater flipped and an aluminum plate added on top of the heater. For info on the aluminum plate, see https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:195653. More information on the flipped MK1 heater orientation on a MakerFarm i3v is available as part of my build thread on 3dprintboard at post http://3dprintboard.com/showthread.php?3461-MakerFarm-8-quot-i3v-Prusa-build-by-Printbus&p=103977&viewfull=1#post103977

NOTE: This works fine with an 8-inch i3v where the rear of the y-bed does not extend rearward over the cross-brace of the printer frame. Those with larger versions of the i3v may need to verify there is adequate clearance for the mounting hardware used if their y-bed extends over that cross member.

The openSCAD source is provided for those wishing to tailor the strain relief design.

Notes:

The strain relief brackets are intended to be printed upside down from how they are installed on the printer. Support may need to be added to the recessed screw head areas.

print_settings.Notes:: On a Prusa I3 MK2 you can print all parts in one go. :)

description.text:
This has been in my mind a while. I wanted my daughter to see how the bird nests and feed the young. So, I decided to build a "Spy Cam Module" for birds nests. ;)
It's a fairly simple print.
Then this is what you will need to get this up and running:

2017-03-24: Removed lights.zip and replaced it with leds.zip. For some reason the old script stopped working when updating to latest version of MotionEyeOS. So I decided to make the leds turn on and off via sh scripts that runs via cron instead. Read inside the scripts how to do it. :)

2017-03-07: Added live streams: http://nest.snille.net

2017-01-10: Updated the case a bit, it was a little too big when I glued the bird nest together. Also added small "locks" for the back, so it's more stable. All four nests will be placed in the trees soon, just waiting for the last RPiZ. :)

Hardware:

  1. Birds Nest (I'm using this one): https://www.rusta.com/se/fagelholk-p756601270101.aspx
  2. Zero Wifi Kit: https://thepihut.com/collections/raspberry-pi-zero/products/raspberry-pi-zero?variant=18767129476
  3. Raspberry Pi NoIR Camera module: https://thepihut.com/collections/raspberry-pi-camera/products/raspberry-pi-noir-camera-module
  4. Pi Zero Cam Adapter: https://thepihut.com/collections/raspberry-pi-camera/products/raspberry-pi-zero-camera-adapter
  5. Bright Pi: https://www.pi-supply.com/product/bright-pi-bright-white-ir-camera-light-raspberry-pi/
  6. USB hub with Ethernet (sort of optional but makes life easier when setting up): http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=0J2-001S-00071

Oh, and a small piece of transparent plastic to cover the camera lens. Cut it from any annoying packing material. :)

You will have to solder a bit. The PI headers and the Bright-Pi is a kit. Both very easy to build.

Then the software:

  1. MotionEyeOS: https://github.com/ccrisan/motioneyeos/wiki
  2. Some small scripts to turn on and off the LEDs. (in the zip).

Start with the build of the hardware.
All parts are just snap in place or push together. :)

Then install MotionEyeOS on an microSD Card.

Check out the MotioEyeOS Wiki for lodas of good information.
Use my scripts (or make your own) to turn off and on the LEDs.

Of course you shall NOT use the visual lights (LEDs) when the birds are in there!
It's only for show. :) You can even skip to solder them if you want...

I'm writing this just out of the top of my head, if you want to know more, just ask. :)

Open up the SketchUp file if you want to make your own version. :)

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Steel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

On a Prusa I3 MK2 you can print all parts in one go. :)

Remove side strips.

Just cut away the two side strips on the clamp part, to be able to slide the box on it. They are only there for support when printing.

Removable module.

The idea is that you can put this in any of your birdhouses. The only thing you need to do is to screw the clamp part to the bird house and drill a hole in the back for the cable. When you are done watching your birds nesting. You can just pull out the whole camera house and waint until next year. :)

comments.text:
This is very good and an excellent write up, thank you for sharing. I came upon this after completing (almost) a similar project which also used a Pi ZeroW and Motioneyeos. As I had a number of IR LEDs in my tool box, I wired three of these in series to provide the illumination, connecting them to the 5V supply which means that they are always on.
Like you, I am also streaming my camera & will be able to watch from wherever I am. I’m also thinking of using the motion detect facility in Motioneyeos to capture some footage but will need to think about this - don’t want to fill my MicroSD card in a matter of hours
comments.author: Alzibiff

comments.text:
Hi! Great to hear! :) I'm actually turning the leds on and off with Cron so they are only lit between 16:00 - 08:00 (in my timezone) witch is basically when it's dark, that's why I used the "Bright PI" thing... But If I would want something more, is should have been a light sensor. I may add that later on.
Regarding motion sensing, I'm actually using that as well, I have a "Smart Mirror" that shows the camera picture when something is moving. :)
I'll add a picture. Also I'm using a "Hub" server with MotionEye to receive all the streams from all cameras to collect them all (check the "Scenarios" https://github.com/ccrisan/motioneyeos/wiki/Usage-Scenarios#multiple-devices-with-a-hub , I'm using the "Multiple devices with a Hub". Regarding the recording, I only save moves on motion and only for one day. If I want to save them longer I have to remember to download. :)

My scaling up means the gap between the base and lid also increase proportionately, and in your case, scaling down means your gap has also decreased proportionately.  I guess the lesson here is don't mess around with a good design, he he he.  That is, unless you know what your doing, which I obviously didn't. :P
comments.author: loco

comments.text: Scaling parts that have to fit together with a specific clearance like this is tricky. If you scale it up by 150%, it also scales the gap between the two parts up by 150%, so it's too lose. And in the other direction, if you scale down by 50%, the gap is 50% as side, and it might be too tight. You'd have to do some math to work out exact percentages, but I'd suggest scaling the outer part slightly less than the inner part so that the clearance between the two is constant.

title: Mendel Y Motor Bracket for Ball Chain

description.text:
This is a redesigned motor bracket for the Mendel Y axis, intended for use with ball chain. As the ball chain gear needs to be fixed to the end of the NEMA17 shaft, and the NEMA17 shaft is shorter than the standard Mendel Y Motor Bracket is thick, this version has a recess for the NEMA17 to fit into, allowing more shaft to protrude.
The ball chain cannot negotiate tight corners, so the idler on the motor bracket is abandoned and a 608 bearing with fender washers (M8x25 is good) on each side is used as a pulley to guide the chain to the deposition bed. A similar pulley arrangement now takes the place of the Y Idler Bracket, which is no longer required.
The motor is raised up so that the chain or belt will not clash with the M8 bracing, and no idler roller is needed.

Print and use. You may wish to see if additional washers need fitting between the bracket and the first fender washer, depending on the length of the shaft on your NEMA17. If using ball-chain see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2009 for the gears. Attach the chain to the deposition bed using pieces of hosepipe or metal strip screwed down tight from underneath. Be prepared to adjust the tension as ball chain has a wearing-in period. The mendel_misc.inc file is found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2192

I wanted a suicide knob for my truck so I took the liberty to make my own.

Printed with two colors for the embossed Cummins logo. 0.025 mm layer height works well. I used ABS for the print on a QIDI Tech I. Print the top clamp piece solid so it has enough strength. The other parts can be lightweighted.

Screw holes are for #6 machine screws but they'll need drilled out. The center hole is for a socket head cap screw to thread into the knob. I uses a #10 screw and had to drill things out for a better fit. Sized to fit a steering wheel of 1.125" diameter.

Edit: Added a fillet to the top clamp because mine broke off at the stud. Should make it stronger. Also uploaded the knob without a logo.

I made this to act as an approximate guide of what my tablet remote is for my outdoor holder model. I realized as I was typing this up that I am missing the buttons on the side but I got the power button, usb and audio jack so it's pretty close.

Figured I'd upload it in case anyone else has a need for something like this in the future.

2 dividing wild-type Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells reconstructed from a scanning electron microscope data, 4000x magnification. The cell membrane on these is bubbly- packed with 'blebs'. Scanning electron microscope images by Jess Holz, 3D reconstruction by Ahmadreza Baghaie in the laboratory of Dr. Zeyun Yu, UW-Wisconsin Milwaukee Computer Science Department: https://pantherfile.uwm.edu/yuz/www/bmv/index.html

3D reconstruction from scanning electron microscope data

Created by 3d reconstruction from a stereo-pair of scanning electron microscope images, taken at about 8 degrees tilt relative to each other. The algorithm creates a dense reconstruction in a manner not entirely unlike 123d catch. The algorithm was developed by the laboratory of Dr. Zeyun Yu, University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee Computer Science Department. See our latest paper by Tafti et al: 3DSEM++: Adaptive and intelligent 3D SEM surface reconstruction, available here: http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0968432816300750

Original scanning electron microscopy data by Jess Holz 3d reconstruction.

title: Chair Slider Foot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
One of our dining room chairs was missing slider feet on its legs. We have tried many commercial sliders, both stick on and nail on with no success.

Today I did a simple design in OpenSCAD. I matched the dimensions of the sliders on the other chairs so all chairs sit at the same height.

I printed the sliders in red ABS and attached with small tack nails. They slide great!

Printer Brand:

100%

Notes:

Use whatever printing temps give you a really solid strong part in your favorite material. Strength is important, since these have a lot of stress on them when someone sits in the chair.

Designed in OpenSCAD based on dimensions of original slider part

I used OpenSCAD to design the part. The source code is included, if you need a part which is similar but with slightly different dimensions. Just change the parameter variables at the top of the file, re-render and export the STL. Good luck!

print_settings.Notes:: Printing time approx 6-7h (main body 4 h 30 min)

title: Tyre Truer MKIII for slot cars 1/32

description.text:
It all started with the idea to push the limits of the 3D printing to create a precision tool that I could have made out of metal instead. The first version was without real bearings so after a while the main bearing started to get clearance but I had proved myself that it could be possible to create a tool to be used for the slot car hobby with repetitive and reasonable results.

This is the evolution of the first tyre truer I designed and printed few month ago.
Few useful features have been added such as:

  • the use of three bearings 626-2Z (6x19x6 mm) which will give stability to the grinding spindle
  • new grinding wheel with double support
  • possibility to connect the vacuum cleaner tube (an adapter for a 35 mm hose is included)
  • the separation wall between the motor and the grinding wheel
  • motor cover
  • grinding wheel protection
  • electrical switch
  • conduit for electrical cables
  • ventilation for the driving motor
    etc. etc.

Updates V01

  • main body (changed the fulcrum of the swing arm)
  • main and secondary pulleys (easier alignement)
  • added the new grinding wheel + axial spacers (tested the wheel and it works very fine)
  • added the electrical cable clamp
  • added the vacuum adapter to fit my Dyson's 35mm ID

Updates V02

  • improved clearances based on the 3D printed parts
  • common size for all steel shafts, now all dia. 6 mm except the tyre spindle (3/32")

Updates V03
I added Gv-013_1 grinding wheel drum V03 since some users experienced some errors on the V02 file of the drum

Cheers,
JamieG

Printer:

Velleman Vertex K8400

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,20

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The first parts I printed were the body and the spindle holder to make sure the printed parts fit together with the correct clearances. I am not sure my printer is perfectly calibrated so please let me know if you find excessive clearance between the two main parts.
All the remaining bits and pieces are quite fast to print and could be printed in one lot but I preferred to print them individually to avoid much jumping from one component to the other during the printing process with possible lower quality of the final print.

Printing time approx 6-7h (main body 4 h 30 min)

Required hardware

The hardware you need is the following:

  • 3 bearings 6x19x6 mm 626-2Z
  • 1 grounded steel shaft dia. 6 mm, 78 mm length
  • 1 grounded steel shaft dia. 6 mm, 68 mm length
  • 1 grounded steel shaft dia. 3/32", 76 mm length
  • 3 grub screws M3 x 6 mm
  • 1 grub screw M3 x 3 mm for the motor pulley* (see note)
  • 1 screw M3 40 mm long here you need to file and fiddle a little (the best is if you have a lathe to shape the hear down to 4 mm so it fits into the recess of the pivot shaft)
  • 4 M3 nuts to lock the knob (1 is inserted - after warming up the nut - into the knob; the other two are needed as a stopper to regulate the depth of the grinding on the wheel and most importantly to be able to help holding still the screw while inserting the knob)
  • 3 standard slot car bronze bushings (I have quite few slot.it and NSR -nsrslot.it- bushings but you have to file away one flange since they are double flanged - here again a small lathe is helpful)
  • 4 M3 self tapping screws to connect the covers
  • 2 M2 screws approx 10 mm long (I changed the thread to M3) with washers to connect the motor to the main body
  • 1 electric DC motor (i.e. DC 6V-12V 6500RPM Large Torque JOHNSON 385 Motor Carbon Brush DC Motor for Tools - http://www.ebay.com/itm/262443105339?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT)
  • 1 on-off switch to be press fitted into the slot of the main body (I don't remember where i bought it - dimensions 17,5x12,5 mm approx)
  • 1 electrical cables suitable for the application (I used some redundant cables with crocodile clips already installed)

(*) I had already a motor with installed the previously made brass pulley. I am not entirely sure the plastic PLA will have a long life since the motor shaft is getting quite hot!!!

Tools

Since this tools is meant to have a good precision, it is recommended the use of reamers.
With the latest design I standardized all metal shafts to dia. 6 mm to limit the number of tools required.
There is the need of a dia. 4,9 mm drill bit (sharp) to ream the hole where the bushings for the tyre spindle will sit.
You will need also different sizes of drill bits to refine all the holes present in the different parts. I discourage the use of electric tools, use only hand tools to get a better feeling and precision.
An M3 tap is also required to shape all threads. Use a drill bit dia. 2 to refine the hole before threading.
For the boring of bearings seats (dia. 19mm) I was lucky I had a 19 mm drill so I carefully redressed by hand the seats. If you don't have it, then you have to make sure the refine the seats that the bearings can be pressed in with a slightly tight fit.

The remaining tools are the usual ones, files, sand paper, screw drivers, soldering iron, etc.

Assembly

Connect the spindle holder to the main body inserting the 68 mm long shaft.
Insert the pivot pin #1 into the main body with the hole accessible since next thing you have to fiddle a little inserting the M3 40mm long screw. the modified head should fit completely into the recess.
Next insert the pivot pin #2 into the spindle holder making sure it is aligned with the screw.
first add a couple of M3 nuts and tight them together toward the upper extremity so you have something to hold the screw when inserting it into the pivot pin #2 and later when you will add an extra nut and the knob.
Press fit the bearings by hand or with the help of a bench clamp with soft jaws being extremely careful to not apply pressure to the inner bearings. the press fit should be enough to keep them in place but they might be glued into place (some loctite-ish 648 could be applied but I haven't tested the compatibility with the PLA yet)
Insert the 78 mm long shaft into the bearings, one spacer, grinding wheel with the sanding roll and then the next spacer. Here it can be tricky since the grounded shafts can be very tight on the bearings. Do not hammer them into the bearings because you will damage them. Get some sand paper and reduce the diameter, usually it can be just 100 of a millimeter. The shaft should slide with a light fit, no clearance must be present between the shaft and inner bearing.
After you have successfully inserted the grinding wheel into position it is time to slightly move aside the sanding roll to be able to access the locking grub screw. Do not tighten the grub screw too hard, here or in any other component. Set the sanding roll back in position.
Insert the motor into the body, plug in the switch and solder the cables. The motor is quite tight so you have to fiddle a little with it but there is enough space to insert it even with the pulley installed.
Insert the tyre spindle bushing with the 76 mm long shaft dia 3/32" without inserting them into the seats and then superglue the bushings into the spindle holder seats making sure the shaft rotate freely = no misalignment.
Add the covers and the remaining pulleys and you are ready to install the tyre to be grinded to size. You will need a couple of aluminium retainers with grub screw to avoid the tyre spindle is moving sideways. The best is to have a couple from the usual specialized suppliers of slot cars.

Grinding process

It is recommended to glue the tyres to the hub but this you should know it already.
Do not use excessive force between the spindle and the grinding wheel. First you will unnecessary heat up the revolving parts, damage the motor and spoil a set of new tyres.
Apply a step by step procedure, let it grind until you feel that there no more pressure and the motor is spinning freely. Stop and check time to time to see the result and possibly measure the diameter of tyre. When you are almost finished with the first tyre, set the two nuts to have them into position as a stopper toward the pivot pin #2 so you can replicated the second tyre with precision. Take the final extra pass on the first tyre and you are ready to move to the next one.
PS: don't forget to round the tyre's edges while you are at it and you can refine the texture of the tyre with same fine sandpaper (the sanding rolls comes with maybe a too rough grain - probably 120).

I have done few tests and the results have been very good.
I have also tested two wheels at the same time but I would not recommend it except for roughing them initially. I don't like to work on the side of the grinding wheel since the underneath grub screw that could have caused some tiny distortion of the grinding wheel.

Have fun and drive carefully ;-)

print_settings.Notes:: This is scaled to 100mm tall, but you can set it to whatever size you want. I did this with 4 bottom layers (use 0 top or you will seal the sound hole!) and 5 perimeters, which is really thicker than necessary, next time I would use 4 for a drum this size. Altering the number of solid bottom layers will directly affect the sound. 4 layers is just right for this size, but use fewer if scaling down. Experiment and have fun. There is no head or thickness on the object, it is entirely controlled by bottom layer and perimeter thickness. ETA for print of 100mm tall was 5:50, but it actually finished in 3:01. Prints nice and easy because of the simple geometry (even using cheap PLA!). I find PLA actually is slightly more vibrant for drums than ABS, but it is a minor difference. My Rostock is actually a v3, not v2. Make sure infill is off, or it will not be hollow.

author: kevinjay4

description.text:
Here's Asoga. She is a great model for your desk. And she can also hold a phone. Place the phone on her feet and she will keep it standing.

Note: I recommend you stick her to the table with a two-sided sticking tape to make sure she doesn't fall and drop the phone when you try to handle it or when she spins from the phone vibrating.

Poser 11

Started the design with Poser 11 (which is free to use for 7 days). The last version of Poser I have used before 11 is 2. What I used Poser 2 for once upon a time was animate people kicking footballs. It was pretty interesting activity for a boy. Quite a lot has changed 9 versions later but the software is extremely easy to get used to. The model has some flaws because of me being a newbie to the software but it is a good proof of concept to myself. I am pretty sure I'll buy it once I have some cool idea of a model that incorporates people posing.

I strongly recommend you try Poser. It's free for 7 days and you'll create great things in no time. Watch their promo video at least.

Meshmixer

When I thought "Enough playing with that body" I got the model exported to .OBJ. .OBJs are easy to import in Meshmixer so that's what I did. I cut a bit of her bottoms (her hands, legs and ass) to make sure she will stand stable on the table and of course she will have better adhesion to the printer bed. I also scaled her to be a reasonable size that will hold a phone. You can see the .OBJ file is quite small while the .MIX and .STL files are in a good size.

Sketchup

I tried loading from Poser to Sketchup. Tried both .dae and .obj files. Neither worked well. Tried the .stl exported from Meshmixer as well and this was the closest I got to using sketchup for finishing touches. Still, the model got imported with some messed up mesh with missing lines an surfaces. And since the model has a lot of those, Sketchup was not an option.

Pose Flaws
  1. While moving the center of mass of the lady I have managed to twist her back in a pose that doesn't look very realistic when looking from behind. Of course the idea is to look at her from the front and this flaw is not visible at all when doing so.
  2. I've messed up the alignment of the two knees horizontally so now when you put your phone on her feet it will be supported by only one of the knees. It still stands pretty stable.
  3. I seem to have moved her lower legs a bit to the back making her knees pop front. This is not visible in the finished model.
  4. The lower and higher of her legs seem to merge together instead of the muscles being squashed so they just touch. It's a minor flaw.
  5. The twisted back seems to have "torn" her panties a bit and now they go through her hips. This won't be visible when painted.
  6. Too much genitalia. Sorry. I used pants on her while designing then replaced it with panties and didn't see stuff was to obvious.

I printed the model with PLA. The left hand unstuck from the bed at some point so I used masking tape to keep it stuck. Still, the layer where this happened was kind of off for the whole print. The print took about 8 hours to finish. The weak spots of the model are surely her hands. Even though I used supports generated by Cura, they did not touch the inner part of her hands so I also needed to fit some "supports" (made of paper) in there while the print was ongoing. The final result looked OK though it was obvious it would need some sanding especially in area where the hand got broken.

A lot of sanding is needed when you want to make a good finished model. This one is hard to sand especially in the area where her body bends the most. Also there are glitches in the design that can go invisible when this is sanded well. The process took a couple of hours. While doing it I managed to lose the pinky on her right hand so Asoga will be a little disabled.
The print would have "liked" a bit of filler in some points but I am satisfied enough with it.

I painted the hair first in some mixture of black and brown. Applied a couple of coats to give a little highlight to the top of the head where light should be hitting.

Then I proceeded with painting the flesh. Used some rusty color for a little shading and white for highlighting (of course mixed with flesh color).

Gave her a face with some eyes (white, brown and black used) and mouth (red and flesh color mixed).

Then I painted the shirt. It was a mixture of yellow and white. Used just a drop of blue for shading. I left the panties for the end which was a mistake since this is the place where the hardest to paint curves are. It would've been much simpler if I started there and then covered all mistakes around. The final touch was adding some finger nails (my print has 19 fingers) where I used black and white glossy paints.

A lot of colors were used. I used Revell paints. I could've been braver with highlighting but that's a note to myself for my next miniature painting.

Here go some thanks to:
  • Poser 11 for offering 7 days of free experimental usage;
  • Meshmixer for making it easy to get 3D models printer-ready for free;
  • Cura for converting STLs to gcode easily and for free;
  • 3D Printing Nerd for his video on finishing 3D prints;
  • Miniwargamer Jay for his tutorials on painting miniatures;
  • Tabletop Minions for the tutorial on how to make your own wet palette;

description.text:
An updated version of my earlier design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:430050), this version includes stronger spring and gears, weaker pawl, and o-ring tires for traction. The first photograph is of the actual prototype. The second photograph is a screen grab of the cad version. The final photograph is of JersyBeast's knob (see UPDATES below).

Assembly video is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q_Jom7imnNw.

Video of prototype run is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zo1t8SiTtTM.

Video of JersyBeast's knob (see UPDATES below) is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vIy25mTT5O0.

You will need to purchase two #18 o-rings (1 3/16" O.D., 15/16" I.D., 1/8" diameter) and two #111 o-rings (2 1/2" O.D., 2 1/8" I.D., 3/16" diameter), which are available on line, and at plumbing supply / box stores.

Designed using Fusion 360, sliced using Cura 2.3.1, and printed in PLA on an Ultimaker 2+ Extended and Ultimaker 3 Extended.

UPDATES:

1) Thingiverse member JersyBeast requested an "easier on the fingers" knob design and even provided a suggested for the new design. So I have implemented JersyBeast's suggestion and uploaded the result as "Knob and Axle (1).stl". I have not tested it yet, but I recommend printing it at 100% infill, and be very careful not to over-torque the spring using it as the spring or "Chassis Left.stl" axle could snap. @JersyBeast, hope your fingers get better!

2) Printed, tested and uploaded photograph and video of JersyBeast's knob.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1mm

Notes:

Print two each of "Axle.stl", "Wheel.stl" and "Wheel Rear.stl", one each of the remaining parts.

Print "Chassis Left.stl", "Chassis Right.stl", "Knob and Axle.stl" and "Spring.stl" at 100% infill, print remaining at 50% infill.

Prior to assembly, test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary for smooth movement of moving surfaces, and tight fit for non moving surfaces. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding may be required.

Study "Assembly.stl".

I assembled my Spring Motor Rolling Chassis Version 2 as follows:

1) Slide "Knob and Axle.stl" into "Chassis Left.stl", then press "Spring.stl" and "Pawl.stl" onto "Knob and Axle.stl".

2) Slide "Gear Pawl.stl" onto "Knob and Axle.stl".

3) Slide "Gear Spur.stl" onto the axle on "Chassis Left.stl".

4) Press "Chassis Right.stl" onto "Chassis Left.stl".

5) Press one "Axle.stl" onto one "Wheel.stl", then slide into position through "Chassis Left.stl" and "Chassis Right.stl", and secure with remaining "Wheel.stl". Make sure the wheels and axle spin freely.

6) Press "Gear Spur Small.stl" onto the remaining "Axle.stl" in the position shown.

7) Insert the small spur gear and axle assembly into the chassis assembly as shown, then press one each of "Wheel Rear.stl" onto each end of the axle. Make sure the wheels rotated freely.

8) Install one each of #18 o-ring onto "Wheel Front.stl", then one each of #111 o_ring onto "Wheel Rear.stl".

9) Apply light machine oil onto all moving contact surfaces.

We built a few of of these to race, they accelerate rapidly thanks to the beefier spring, and run anywhere between 30 to 50 feet depending upon the lubrication and break in.

Hope you like it!

This is an OpenSCAD version of Tanatof's Spool drawer organizer, created to make it adjustable to different spool sizes.

Still working on refinements, so please let me know if the range of size values is too constrictive for your spools.

Still have some other features I want to do, like rounded corners, and a few others.

UPDATE: 2016-01-03 - Added a parameter where you choose to render one drawer or all of the drawers.

UPDATE 2016-01-08 - Thanks for the feedback, esp. from C. Beauregard for pointing out my radius vs. diameter oops. I've uploaded a new file that should generate the correctly sized drawers!

title: PrintrBot Simple Metal Metric Z Conversion

description.text:
With the PrintrBot Simple Metal approaching end of life, I've been thinking ahead in terms of replacement parts. Most of the parts on the PrintrBot are fairly generic or can at least be (relatively) easily swapped out with industry standard components, but one part that really worried me was the Delrin Z nut. This is one of the only parts on the printer that is both proprietary and consumable; eventually the nut will wear down and will need to be replaced.

Rather than buying a bunch of them to stock up for the future (though at the time of this writing, they are no longer available on the PrintrBot store anyway), I decided to replace the Z movement with a standard 8 mm lead screw that can easily be sourced online for a few dollars.

Beyond maintenance and availability issues, converting the PrintrBot's Z motion to metric can (in theory) improve print quality as the controller doesn't have to convert the metric dimensions of the printed part to the PrintrBot's original imperial threaded rod.

For source and more detailed documentation, please see the GitHub page for this project:

https://github.com/MS3FGX/PBSM_ZNUT

Installation requires the following additional components:

  • M3X15mm Cap Screws (x2)
  • M3 Nut (x1)
  • Brass T8 nut
  • 250mm T8 Lead Screw
  • 5mmx8mm Coupler (Either printed or purchased)

After printing the adapter, press the M3 nut into the bottom and then use the two M3 screws to secure the brass Z nut to the top.

Once you're sure the brass Z nut fits into the adapter, you can remove the PrintrBot's Y arm, Y belt, and Y stepper. You can then remove the two white spacers, Delrin Z nut, 5mm threaded rod, and Z coupling. They will no longer be required, but I would keep them to be safe.

Install the adapter and Z nut in place of the original parts, then thread the lead screw through the top of the brass Z nut and down into the new Z coupling.

Finally, put the Y stepper and belt back on, making sure that the belt isn't rubbing on the aluminum bearing block (you may need to move the sprocket slightly on the shaft). Also check the belt tightness before putting the Y arm back on.

With the new lead screw installed, you'll need to adjust the printer's firmware so that the steps-per-mm matches the new thread. You can use the very handy RepRap Calculator, but assuming you got a standard 4 start T8 lead screw the steps will need to be set to 400.

To do that, you'll need to connect to the printer with your software of choice and execute the M92 code in the GCode input field. You'll then need to save it to the EEPROM with M500.

comments.text:
To use "inch" screw is completely NUT ! :)
Indeed you are right as these will lead to the firmware to convert and because of rounding errors, from time to time it will have to correct which leads to layer thickness slight variation.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: This is the one thing that printrbot does that "grinds my gears", why use imperial spec'd parts, on highly accurate precision machines.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Definitely, even if there was no measurable improvement in the performance of the machine, I would have swapped it just to get rid of the out of place imperial axis.
comments.author: keganholtzhausen

comments.text:
When looking for a 3D printer to get my hand on, I contacted them and asked the full specs. I got them and asked why use "imperial". Answer, because it is standard in the US, I told them I didn't care, that the US automobile industry would be bankrupt if they hadn't moved to metric and wish them good luckbut no way I would buy from them.
All specs in the NIST are in metric !
comments.author: keganholtzhausen

comments.text: For what it's worth, the new 2016 model PrintrBot Simple uses an 8 mm metric lead screw.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: I had been wanting to replace that threaded rod shortly after getting the printer, but never spent any time looking at what it would take.  This looks like a perfect solution.  I saw on git that you did this in OpenSCAD which is also great.  I was thinking of using an anti-backlash nut and might have to enlarge the hole a bit for it.
comments.author: ElmoC

comments.text: I'd love to hear how it works out for you. If you tweak the SCAD file feel free to make a pull request, I'd be happy to make both versions available in the repo. Could probably even get it working in Customizer so people could chose which version they wanted and Thingiverse would spit out the STL for them.
comments.author: ElmoC

comments.text: I was also wondering, do anti-backlash nuts make sense on a Z axis which is only ever really "pushing".
comments.author: ElmoC

comments.text: If you use Z lift, then it pushes and pulls.  I switched to anti-backlash nuts on my C-Bot printer and did notice a difference in quality on the layers.  But that could have been from the other nuts having worn down.
comments.author: keganholtzhausen

title: USB A, USB C, SD and MicroSD holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Remixed from USB and SD holder for wide USB sticks, so it fits wider usb pendrives and adaptors, but I changed three USB Type A holes to four USB Type C. Future proof!
So:

description.text:
The "GidTech Window-Blackout-O-Master 2000™" attachment for a cheap roller blind from Argos. While more expensive, more substantial blinds can have a motor fitted inside the blind tube itself, cheaper roller-blinds have much narrower tubes.

This attachment uses a 100RPM 12V DC motor - https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B01KTZXZ1G - to control the blind.

The motor plate is held on by four M3 bolts (hex-head) going into four captive M3 nuts in the base. First, screw the motor to the plate with three or more M3 screws, then bolt the entire plate onto the frame (pushing on the motor gear first).

The free end of the blind uses the existing fitting for strength, but it should be straightforward to model a new one. If so, I'd recommend increasing the slot width and the diameter of the stalk.

I'm connecting this arrangement via a cheap IBT-2 H-bridge board to an Onion Omega board currently being used to control the "GidTech Blind-Tilt-A-Tron 2000™" -- http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1051809 -- wooden slatted blind controller; it communicates via MQTT to a custom Internet of Things environment. Alternatively, the H-bridge could be connected to an Espruino, an Arduino, an ESP8266, or similar.

You could control the motor with simple up/down buttons or a DPDT rocker switch, or you can use the otherwise-unused "accessory port" holes to mount limit sensors. I've included a partially-developed mount for copper wire brushes to contact against conductive copper tape stuck to the blind; or Hall effect sensors to sense adhered neodymium magnets. However, my favoured approach is the included rotary encoder attachment and third gear wheel so a microcontroller can receive a stream of pulses to maintain blind position.

description.text: A smoking gnome riding a whale propped up by planks of wood. This was created in OpenSCAD as a mashup exercise following the tutorial at: http://www.makerbot.com/tutorials/openscadmashup/ Doing a compile & render took forever until I simplified the meshes I was using with meshlab (see files). I also had to increase the memory for CGAL (edit -> preferences -> advanced). After doing this, I was able to render and export an STL in about 15 minutes.

0.2mm layer height, hollow fill, fine detail.  
Tried printing shell mode and it disintegrated.  With the above settings the object prints fine but there is quite a bit of support material and it's really hard to remove.  I lost a some of the structure near the tail when removing it.  
The intricate plank structure under the whale looks good but if I was doing this again I'd reconsider the design in order to make removal easier.

author: nikiki01

description.text:
LIPO Guards I made for the three common ones I use exclusively, Dinogy Graphene, Dinogy 4S 1350, Tattuu 4S 1550.

These guards are for LIPOs mounted on the bottom of the frame. The two X's on the bottom of the guards is just a way to keep weight down. The open space in between the X spaces is to allow the battery strap to get more velcro security in case the strap doesn't wrap all the way to the other side. I did not bother adding open spaces to the sides or the fronts of the guards in order to keep the print tuning for TPU to a minimum level of complexity, and so that I can print each piece using Simplify3D fast settings, printing as fast as possible. Tip: Use structure support and ooze shield in the case of fast printing.

I did not build tilt for the guards. Instead, I made a small stand which can be used to prop the quad up using the mounted LIPO. This small footprint non-fixed tilt solution makes it convenient to adjust the quad's tilt for take off, and doesn't add any extraneous weight to the guards once you're airborne.

For those of you who race drones, I've customized these two guard / slide plates to support FPV Drone Transponders suitable for use on X-frame style quads. No more using zip tie and 100 mph duck tape. These are available for purchase only. https://www.facebook.com/myvwsbiz/posts/1011824028962668

title: FlashForge Spool Holder for Sainsmart TPU 800g spool

description.text:
This spool holder is designed specifically for the FlashForge Creator Pro dual extruder printer. I looked around for a spool holder on Thingiverse that specifically supports SainSmart spools but couldn't find one with documentation that says I wouldn't be wasting my time printing a part that ultimately wouldn't fit Sainsmart's filament spools. So, I designed this from scratch, did all the manual measurements so I can be sure my first test print would not be a waste of time.

Print this in PLA or ABS or other tougher material. I printed mine in PLA using medium settings in Simplify3D. The tube is hollowed out so you'll need to ensure you add support but, that support, you can't remove and have to leave in place. I did that in order to keep print time and filament use down to a minimum, while taking advantage of the support feature to ensure the tube holder is sturdy and durable.

comments.text: Can you tell me how to best print this in Simplify3D?
comments.author: amarand

comments.text: I've added photos of my FFCP printer as I believe it is the same as yours v2016 edition.
comments.author: amarand

comments.text: Hello amarand, I printed it out using PLA with 100% In-Fill and generate support. PLA is the only rigid material that I have in addition to TPU. You do not want to print this project in TPU. Lol. You'll want to print with PLA with the model oriented on the print bed exactly how it looks in the photo. The support you will remove is under the base plate. The cylinder will also have support but, you can't get to it and it is fine left inside. This was just me being clever to keep print time down. So, rather than make a solid cylinder with increased print time, I left it hollow with support material inside to make it just as sturdy. I manually did all the measurements using a US Inch/CM ruler, for each part of the spool holder. When using a tool such as TinkerCad, I measure and create each component of the spool holder first, and then put them together. Like Lego blocks, if you will. The diameter of the cylinder is a few mm larger than the actual diameter of the hole in the spool. That was probably the only thing that required additional thinking. If there was an app (customizer) that was specific to the type of spool holder for the FFCP, I would've used it. Great idea though and probably a JavaScript dev who has the time could whip one up in no time. Anyways, I hope my reply is helpful.
comments.author: amarand

title: Fanduct for Mankati Full Scale XT Plus (with dual E3DV6 upgrade)

description.text:
Fan Duct for Mankati Full Scale XT Plus with Dual E3DV6 hotends

After equipping my Mankati Fullscale XT Plus 3D printer with two E3D-V6 hotends , the original Mankati fan duct (that left to be desired anyway) did not fit anymore, so I designed a new one.

This fan duct has been designed with the following criteria in mind:
  • The airflow must be led away from the hotends as much as possible
  • The airflow must be surrounding the object being printed from all sides.
  • The fan duct should have a shape that takes friction of the airflow into account, resulting in a constant airflow from all sides of the printed object.
  • When 3D printing the fan duct, no support structures are needed. All angles are steeper then or equal to 45°.
  • The fan duct should be suitable for the 45x45 mm radial fan as is being used in the Mankati printer (among many others).
  • The design is optimized for printing with a 0.4 mm nozzle.

Note: This fan duct will also fit with the original hotends of the Mankati printer in place, and is a considerable improvement over the original Mankati fan duct

Note 2: Since the Mankati printer is in fact an Ultimaker clone (that is just a little bigger) I assume that this fan duct could also be used on an Ultimaker.

Happy printing!

Huib.

Printer:

Mankati Fullscale XT Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Printed with Polymaker PC-Max (black) using a 0.4 mm nozzle.

Hotend temp: 270° C
(Probably actually 255°C since the temp reading is quite a bit off with the Mankati)

Bed temp: 90° C

Bed surface: Buildtak (not quite suitable for these high temperatures).

Total weight of the fanduct (using Polycarbonate) = 24 grams.

title: Replacement panel for rear console ashtray Lexus IS250

description.text:
This is a panel which replaces the ashtray assembly in the rear of the center console on my Lexus IS250. I am planning to replace the ashtray with another power outlet and USB charging port, as well as some switches and indicators for the rear entertainment system.

The sketchup file is a blank panel and a panel with a power outlet and USB cutout already in place. You can customize these however you like using Sketchup.

If you don't want to glue it, you could use the Sketchup files and design some clips to snap it in place. I might update this later with the clips but hot glue is easy to remove so I didn't think it was necessary.

A remix of Jpete24's "Plus" version of the PiGRRL Zero. Printed with ABS

-Independent action buttons
-Railing on the case so the buttons don't spin, if you want to label them A,B,X,Y. (i cant get that level of detail
-Trimmed D-Pad footprint
-Removed speaker rail to allow variations for speaker size
-Reinforced shoulder button mounts
-Notched out a small area on the face-plate that was in the way of the LCD aligning correctly on the mounts
-Added 6mm of Depth to the face-plate to be more forgiving of clearance with wiring.

Additionally, i used the Retropie image Jpete24 links to, while the drivers and system works, the rotation is upside down.
With the SD card mounted on your PC find the file "config.txt" and edit it.
Find this line and change the rotate from 270 to 90
"dtoverlay=pitft22,rotate=270,speed=80000000,fps=60"

Example

--- added by adafruit-pitft-helper Thu 17 Mar 17:11:08 UTC 2016 ---

[pi1]

device_tree=bcm2708-rpi-b-plus.dtb

[pi2]

device_tree=bcm2709-rpi-2-b.dtb

[all]

dtparam=spi=on

dtparam=i2c=off

dtparam=i2c_arm=off

hdmi_force_hotplug=1

hdmi_cvt=320 240 60 1 0 0 0

hdmi_group=2

hdmi_mode=87

dtoverlay=pitft22,rotate=90,speed=80000000,fps=60

--- end adafruit-pitft-helper Thu 17 Mar 17:11:08 UTC 2016 ---

author: yanizo

title: LED light clip for Printrbot Play, fits Ikea Dioder

description.text: A quick little clip for the Printrbot Play that holds LED strip lights along the edges of the case in order to illuminate the print area. This was made to fit the Dioder lights from Ikea, they're kinda expensive for what they are, so I doubt anyone would go out and buy them for this purpose, I just happened to have a set left over from another project. The strips are too long to fit inside the printer, so I had to figure out an external mounting solution. These clips hold onto the metal case with just friction, and the lights snap in fairly securely. They tilt the lights at 45° to illuminate everything inside the printer, while staying away from any moving parts. This is my first time using friction to hold parts in place, I have no idea if this will hold long-term, or if the grip will lessen over time, it may need a dab of rubber cement (or other non-permanent glue), or possibly printed at 95% scale, etc.

This is a nice key chain about a guitar for the Musician Ian De Vera.
Printed in Flex filament is an excelent Gift.

Si lo imprimien en fliamento Flex será muy duradero

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/BB5353W3wzs" ></iframe>

Design this in a Rhinocero course.
I took an image of a guitar (Google Images) I used it in the background and drew with pieces of circles the outline then extrude it, the rest of the things are basic geometric shapes.
Then I subtracted a cylinder, so that it looks like an acoustic guitar.
I reversed the design to add the text "IAN DE VERA" which is the name of the musician, in the back.
I gave away several samples already turned into a keychain with the addition of a small metal ring.

Diseñe esto en un curso de Rhinocero.
Tomé una imagen de una guitarra (Google Imagenes) La usé de fondo y dibujé con rozos de circulos el contorno luego la extruí , el resto de las cosas son formas básicas geometricas.
Luego le resté un cilindro, para que parezca una guitarra acustica.
Invertí el diseño para agreguegarle el texto "IAN DE VERA" que es el nombre del músico, en la parte de atrás.
Regalé varias muestras ya convertidas en llavero con el agregado de un arito metálico.
Personal Course 2015

description.text:
I like to just throw my Oral-B electric toothbrush into my wash bag when traveling. To protect the bristles, I created a small snap-on cover for the head. There are different versions of the Oral-B heads, and I created two covers. The first one, "round", is a snug fit for the standard round Precision Clean heads. The second one, "elongated", is more universal, and fits the larger elongated FlossAction and ProWhite heads, but can also be used with the round standard heads. It just wiggles a bit on the smaller heads.

Prints without support and rafts, using all default settings.

My first attempt of a Stewart Platform (6 Degrees of freedom) using (6) EMax Ex08MAII servos. I used M3x10 screws and the servo linkage is formed from 1mmø paper clip wire. I was unable to correctly calculate the servo angles so I have moved to a servo linear actuator style to eliminate actuator rotation effect. I have included my excel calculator along with the files for reference. It correctly calculates the actuator length but incorrectly calculates servo angle due to the actuators relative rotation. Any input regarding this would be appreciated. Will post linear actuator version soon.

A vector for use in laser cutting, based on transmission electron microscopy cross sections of neurons in the brain. Specifically the image shows the protective myelin sheath (shaded areas) which wraps around neurons. Myelin is what degenerates in multiple sclerosis.

Note there are 3 separate power settings for the lines in this file: etch (outer circles), cut through (inner circles), and raster (shading).

title: 3D Model - Black Sand Magnet Recycle Old Hard Drive Magnets

description.text:
This is a work in progress and More then happy for suggestions or modifications.

Required components to make this usable.

1) Hard drive magnets from old hard drive/hard disk
2) Piece of string that is strong enough to lift the magnet from its payload
3) Non magnetized separating rings from between hard drive plates

This is designed to work similar to a black sand recovery magnet, separating magnetic items from non magnetic.

Additionally I have found it useful in picking up dropped sewing pins and releasing them back onto a bench or holder.

Sign posts! How else will your adventurers know where to go?

This model comes in two sets. You will print the sign post then print as many signs for it as you want. The pieces can be glued together.

If you like my models please consider tipping or check out my Patreon page. These help with the wasted plastic prototypes and time trying to make these models perfect.

Also check out my Instagram or Facebook for fun DnD and 3D printing pictures!

This is a bridge pier for a railroad bridge. The dimensions are taken from an actual pier built by the Southern Pacific Railroad for a crossing of Los Gatos Creek in the Santa Clara Valley, California. I found dimensions in a set of Southern Pacific technical drawings at the California State Railroad Museum in Sacramento.

I printed these on a Form One resin printer. The walls may be too thin for ABS / PLA printers; filling in the hollow interior should make it easier to print. I've included the SketchUp file used to generate the STL file. Note that hollow models can have problems on liquid resin printers because of pressure when the tank presses against the model after each layer. The pier has a small hole at the top of the hollow section to allow resin to escape.

For more details on making the model, and on the scene I created the pier for, check out
http://vasonabranch.blogspot.com/2016/12/wrights-bridge-2-3d-printing-all-details.html

author: ppet36

print_settings.Notes:: I recommend .3 layer height, 1.8mm perimeter, and 2 bottom layers on one half,  4 on the other. (make sure to turn off top layer or it will cap it for you) Break glaze and smooth the edge before bonding together by rubbing on sandpaper on a flat surface. ABS with acetone or PLA with superglue both work well, sidewall is thick to help it stick. I am still experimenting with different head thicknesses, but so far .6-1.2 is my favorite. (Update 2-12-17, on the wide flat version I like printing at .2 layer height and using 2 layers on one side and 4 or 5 on the other, it gives a good low-high combo) Sidewall thickness also influences sound, but beware if you reduce it much it will start to be more flexible, which might weaken or break the bond. I use about 1 1/2 tsp of #6 glass beads available at most craft stores. I go for just enough to cover the head about 2ish layers deep. Your preference may vary. Mute and unmute the ends to vary sound, shake end to end or side to side, tap the heads on the palm of your cupped hand or your leg and you will be amazed at the wide range of sounds you can get out of this guy. The pictures of the big blue one show before and after sanding. A big difference in the fit and is a quick but important step.

Doesn't Matter
